verses.text: 到末後的日子，耶和華殿的山，必矗立在萬山之上，高舉過於萬嶺；萬民都要流歸這山。

words.note: Abbreviation for '以賽亞書' (Book of Isaiah).
Refers to the eschatological period.
Implicit in 耶和華殿的山 as 'mountain of Jehovah's temple'.
A formal or classical way of saying 'above'.

verses.text: 必有多國的人前來說：「來吧！我們上耶和華的山，登雅各 神的殿；他必把他的道路指示我們，我們也要遵行他的道；因為教訓必出於錫安。耶和華的話要來自耶路撒冷。

words.note: The preceding space indicates reverence for 'God'.
Often refers to God's moral ways or teachings.
Short for '道路', God's way or truth.
Refers to divine instruction or doctrine.

verses.text: 「他要在多族中施行審判，為遠方的強國斷定是非。他們必把刀劍打成犁頭，把矛槍打成鐮刀；這國不舉刀攻擊那國，他們也不再學習戰事。
各人都要坐在自己的葡萄樹，和無花果樹下，無人驚嚇他們，因為萬軍之耶和華親口說過了。

words.note: Often used in the title 'LORD of hosts' (萬軍之耶和華).
Classical Chinese particle, often similar to '的'.

verses.text: 雖然，萬民各奉自己神的名行事，我們卻要永遠奉耶和華我們 神的名而行。」

words.note: Implies acting respectfully or by command of.
Here refers to a general god or idol, not the biblical God.
Implies acting respectfully or by command of.
The preceding space indicates reverence for 'God'.
Connects verbs, often showing consequence or manner.

verses.text: 耶和華說：「到那日，我必召聚瘸腿的，集合被趕散的，和我所苦待的。

words.note: Transliteration of the Hebrew name for God.
A common biblical phrase referring to the Day of the Lord.
Lit. 'lame leg'

verses.heading: Restoration Will Follow Crisis

verses.text: 我必使瘸腿的作餘民；使軟弱疲乏的成為強國；耶和華必在錫安山作王統治他們，從現在直到永遠。

words.note: Lit. 'lame leg'
Lit. 'remaining people'
Transliteration of the Hebrew name for God.
A prominent hill in Jerusalem, significant in the Bible.

verses.text: 你這羊群的守望樓啊！錫安女子的俄斐勒啊！從前的權柄，必歸給你，就是耶路撒冷女子的國權，要歸還給你。

words.note: A poetic name for Jerusalem.
Often used metaphorically for the inhabitants of a city/nation.
A fortified hill in Jerusalem, near the Temple.
Capital of ancient Judah and Israel.
Often used metaphorically for the inhabitants of a city/nation.

verses.text: 現在你為甚麼大聲呼喊？難道你們中間沒有君王嗎？或是你的謀士滅亡了，以致疼痛抓緊你，好像臨產的婦人呢？

words.note: Lit. 'for what'
Lit. 'big sound'

words.definition: so that, with the result that

verses.text: 錫安的女子啊！你要疼痛劬勞，好像臨產的婦人；因為現在你要從城裡出來，住在田野，一定要到巴比倫去；在那裡你要蒙拯救，在那裡耶和華必救贖你，脫離仇敵的掌握。

words.note: A poetic name for Jerusalem.
Often used metaphorically for the inhabitants of a city/nation.
A literary term, often used for labor pains in childbirth in biblical contexts.
Ancient city in Mesopotamia, significant in biblical history.
Often implies receiving something from a superior or higher power.
Transliteration of the Hebrew name for God.

verses.text: 現在多國的民集合起來，攻擊你，說：『願錫安被蹂躪，願我們親眼看見錫安遭報應。』」

words.note: Often found in literary or formal contexts, including biblical.
Refers to a just consequence for actions, often negative.

verses.text: 但是，他們卻不知道耶和華的意念，也不明白他的謀略；他收集他們，好像把禾捆收集到禾場一樣。

words.note: Refers to bundles of harvested grain, used in agricultural contexts.
An area where grain is threshed to separate it from chaff.

verses.text: 錫安的女子啊！起來踹穀吧！因為我必使你的角成為鐵，使你的蹄成為銅；你必粉碎許多民族，毀滅他們所得的不義之財，作為祭物獻與耶和華，把他們的財寶獻給全地的主。

words.note: A traditional method of separating grain by trampling it with feet or animals.
Indicates 'that which' or 'what is'.
An idiom referring to wealth acquired unjustly.
A gift offered to a deity.
More formal or classical equivalent of '跟' or '給'.
Used as a title for God in Christian contexts.
